Review Recent progresses in graphene-based (photo)catalysts for reduction of nitro compounds Mahmoud Nasrollahzadeh * Zahra Nezafat Mostafa Ghafori Gorab Mohaddeseh Sajjadi Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Qom, Qom, 37185-359, Iran Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science University of Qom Qom 37185-359 Iran Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Qom, Qom 37185-359, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The rapid progresses in the reduction of nitro compounds represent a potent and extensively utilized transformation, which allows the introduction of amino compounds. From the standpoint of organic chemistry, amines have many applications in the synthesis of drugs, biologically active molecules, pharmaceutical products, dyes, polymers, etc. For this aim and owing to the environmental concerns about toxic nitro contaminants such as 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), up to know, much research has been carried out on the reduction/degradation of nitroarenes for the fabrication of amines using different heterogeneous (nano)catalysts. This review provides the current developments in the area of production, classification and applications of graphene-based catalysts in the reduction of nitro compounds to amines. The application of graphene derivatives in the synthesis of various catalysts is advantageous compared to other catalysts and thus increases the rate of reduction of nitro compounds. The use of these catalysts offers several benefits such as straightforward work-up, high catalytic prowess and recovery. Keywords Nitroarenes Graphene-based catalysts Reduction Pollutants 1 Introduction Water pollution with organic pollutants such as nitro compounds; especially 2-nitrophenol (2-NP) and 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), referred to as “priority pollutants’’ owing to their superior solubility and stability in water, has become an important environmental subject and received significant attention in the 21st century. Up till now, a diversity of technologies has been exploited to convert nitro pollutants to amines [1–6]. Generally, three methods including catalytic reduction, photocatalytic degradation and adsorption are used to remove water pollutants [7]. Toxic nitrophenols can be easily converted into aminophenols by catalytic reduction processes [5,6,8]. From the application perspective, developing technologies possessing innovative features such as reduction process is really an effective strategy to eliminate toxic pollutants (especially nitroarenes). Reduction/degradation is a fundamental chemical reaction in organic synthesis. Aminoarenes, which are essential ingredients for the fabrication of pigments, pesticides, dyes, plastics, and pharmaceuticals, play an important role in the corresponding chemical industries [5–7,9–12]. The derivatives of amines are usually obtained by several approaches, one of which is the reduction of nitroarenes using effective catalysts [5–9,13–15]. Consequently, various nitroarenes; especially 4-NP and 2-NP, can be reduced to their amino counterparts, 4-aminophenol (4-AP) and 2-aminophenol (2-AP), respectively, via the use of the heterogeneous (nano)catalysts [13]. The catalytic reduction of nitroarenes by heterogeneous (nano)catalysts has attracted significant consideration due to clean processing, easy operation, economic nature and high efficiency. Accordingly, the suitable design of the heterogeneous (nano)catalysts and their careful selection can considerably improve the reduction performance, thereby making further catalytic sustainability and efficiency [16]. With the increasing need for the greener aspect of the catalytic reaction systems, the advancement of environmentally benign and more efficient procedures, which could be ideally conducted in aqueous media, is greatly desired. Today, various (nano)catalytic reduction processes have been developed based on avoiding the utilization of toxic/volatile organic solvents and reducing agents such as NaBH4, which is a water soluble reductant and an alternative hydrogen source [5,6,17]. In this regard, graphene-based (nano)catalysts are suitable candidates for these catalytic reductions, particularly for nitroarenes reduction. One of the usual allotropic forms of carbon is graphite, which contains sp2-hybridized carbon atomic layers [18]. In 2004, Geim and colleagues effectively isolated single layer graphene nanosheets via engaging a peeling procedure containing a scotch tape [19]. Graphene, as a hexagonally flat layer carbon sheet, is widely used in the areas of catalysis, chemical sensors, hydrogen storage and field emitters, owing to its special properties/features with respect to physics, material science, chemistry and mechanic [20–24]. For example, graphene and its analogues have prominent specific surface area (∼2630 m2 g−1), high electron mobility (∼15 × 103 cm2V−1), thermal conductivity (∼5 × 103 Wm−1 K−1) at room temperature, electrical conductivity (∼7200 Sm−1), strong chemical stability, excellent optical transparency (∼97 %), tensile strength (∼130 GPa), high mechanical with a Young’s modulus of ∼1100 GPa, high capacity of metal immobilization and low preparation cost [19,25–27]. Graphene is a good option for application as a sustainable and excellent (nano)catalyst support [28,29] due to the high immobilization of metal/metal oxide nanoparticles (NPs) on its surface or between layers for preparing more efficient heterogeneous (nano)catalysts [5,6,30–32]. Its extraordinary conductivity can facilitate electron transfer during various transformations. In fact, graphene-based (nano)composites have several properties, which can affect their efficiency as promising (nano)catalysts. Their electrical and thermal conductivity can be specifically useful in several processes because of the electric polarization and charge transfer at local points, which can take place between graphene and substrates in some of the reaction steps [33–35]. Indeed, the transfer of electric density from graphene to supported metal/metal oxide NPs deposited on graphene was mostly invocated to realize the (nano)catalytic activity/efficiency of the as-prepared graphene-based metal/metal nanocatalysts. In addition, the substrate activation can be carried out via electron donation from graphene sheets. Among other various derivatives of graphene, graphene functionalized via metal/metal oxide NPs has attracted considerable attention for many new fields of applications in recent years [6,27,36]. Another graphene-based material is GO (graphene oxide), a delaminated layer from graphite oxide in the sp2-hybridized configuration [37–40]. GO can comprise a high oxygen proportion, in some instances much further than that of carbon, thereby it can oxidize to form epoxy and/or hydroxyl functional groups onto basal plane, carbonyl and/or carboxyl groups located in the zigzag edges [41,42]. Given the ease of fabrication in large quantities and its many functional groups, GO is generally one of the preferred graphene-based materials compared with other carbon-based materials such as carbon nanotubes [26,43]. Accordingly, GO-based (nano)materials can be one of the preferred graphene analogues as (nano)catalysts. Metal salts or NPs can be simply immobilized on GO surface due to presence of functional groups such as hydroxyl, epoxide and carboxyl at the bottom and top surface of each sheet [26,36]. GO and reduced GO (rGO) are graphene derivatives based on these diverse materials. There have been progresses in the field of nanotechnology and nanoscience [26,44,45]. Considering their exceptional properties, graphene-based nanostructures with high catalytic activity are one of the excellent selections for the production of diverse organic compounds [46–51]. The form, surface morphology and size of the particles are extremely critical in catalytic properties of the metal nanoparticles [1,26]. With regards to the greener aspect of the catalytic (nano)systems, developing most facile and environmentally benign strategies in the efficient remediation of toxic/hazardous nitroarenes is of specific significance worldwide [52]. In the last ten years, few papers have reported graphene, GO and functionalized graphene-based resources as suitable supports in the reduction of nitroarenes using aqueous NaBH4. In the reduction of nitroarenes to useful aminoarenes with NaBH4 reductant in aqueous media, electrons can be transferred from BH4 − to nitro groups when both species are chemically absorbed on the graphene-based nanocatalyst surface. This review reports remarkable advantageous of graphene-based supports in the fabrication of non-toxic and novel catalysts. Here, the fabrication graphene-based catalysts is discussed and a better understanding of their utilizations in the reduction of nitroarenes is provided. 2 Synthetic methods of graphene-based (nano)materials Today researchers concentrate on searching for nanocatalysts with high catalytic activity. Therefore, various nanocatalysts have been fabricated by transition metals including Pd, Ag, Au, Co, Ni, Cu, etc. [9,53–56]. Graphene-based NPs can be obtained via decoration of graphene, GO or rGO with various types of NPs such as quantum dots (Q-Ds), noble metals, metal oxides, silica and magnetic NPs [26,36]. A striking synergy could mostly be obtained due to the combination of these exceptional and strong particles. Different ways for decoration of metal NPs on the surface of graphene and their analogues include: (a) anchoring diverse NPs via both in situ and ex situ methods to form functionalized graphene [57–59], (b) increasing various NPs on graphene decorated on diverse metal surfaces [60] (c) reducing metal ions in the presence of GO [61–64]. In particular, GO is an encouraging template for this objective due to the presence of O2 containing functional groups on its surfaces along with structure defects, which allow the nucleation, growth and decoration of various metal/metal oxide NPs. Metal NPs immobilized on the graphene surface, GO or rGO can be potentially promoted by the synergetic effects between graphene and less reactive NPs to prepare extremely effective hybrid nanocatalysts [65,66]. In general, in situ methods (e.g. hydrothermal [67–71], reduction [72–77] and electrochemical [78,79]) are based on growing NPs on GO surface while ex situ methods involve the attachment of pre-fabricated NPs onto GO surface [58,80–82]. Scheme 1 provides a summary of different synthetic methods. Graphene -based nanocatalysts are able to offer many advantageous and distinct properties for different utilizations on the basis of outstanding characteristics. The most usual characterization techniques applied for the characterization of graphene-based catalysts include X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Some of the characterization techniques to study graphene-based catalysts are shown in Scheme 2 . In addition, ultraviolet visible spectroscopy (UV–vis) is an appropriate method for monitoring the reduction progress [1,6,17]. For example, 4-NP has a specific surface plasmon resonance (SPR) band at λmax 317 nm. The main goal of this review is the application of graphene in (nano)catalysis for the reduction of nitroarenes. The fabrication of large scale graphene with defect free and high quality nanosheets has become a significant goal and necessary challenge as well as a labor intensive task for scientists worldwide. In this regard, many research efforts have been concentrated on developing and/or improving large scale fabrication of graphene subsequently applied as catalyst and/or catalyst support. Scheme 3 summarizes these preparation procedures. Several graphene preparation routes such as chemical oxidation [83,84], CVD (chemical vapor deposition) [26,85], micromechanical exfoliation of graphite [86,87], epitaxial growing on SiC [26,88], unzipping CNTs and especially chemical reduction of graphite oxide [89] among others have been recently reported. Massive preparation and commercial availability of graphene and its analogues are necessary. Within the top bottom concept, graphene or GO is prepared by exfoliating graphite or graphite oxide. Exfoliation of graphite and/or graphite oxide to give graphene and/or GO has become one of the most encouraging routes for the large scale graphene fabrication at tremendously low cost [90,91]. The separation or detachment of graphene layers from one another is referred to as delamination exfoliation. The resistance to overcome can be the Van der Walls attractions between adjacent graphene/GO flakes. In general, there are three kinds of techniques to exfoliate graphite (oxide) into graphene (oxide) flakes; namely, functionalization, mechanical exfoliation, and intercalative exfoliation. Exfoliation of graphene (oxide) has been performed via the intercalative exfoliation by ionic liquids, polymers and supramolecules, surfactants, small molecules, inorganic salts, and biomolecules (e.g. protein and polysaccharides) [90]. In addition, the mechanical exfoliation of graphite for large scale fabrication of graphene has been performed by sonication, ball milling, fluid dynamic, and supercritical fluid exfoliation. Typically, the mechanical mechanism of sonication in exfoliating graphene could be demonstrated in Fig. 1 [91]. GO, a delaminated layer from graphite oxide (inter layer spacing (d002) of 0.3363 nm), is generally fabricated via the comprehensive graphite oxidation, followed by the exfoliation of ensuing graphite oxide to GO sheets (Fig. 2 ) [92,93]. The aromatic lattice of graphene is interrupted by epoxide, hydroxyl, carbonyl and carboxylic groups. Recently, many reports have been presented on the production of graphene sheets by the chemical reduction of exfoliated graphite oxide, which could be readily employed as a suitable support. GO chemical reduction to graphene has been recently carried out by researchers using different chemical agents, as shown in Table 1 [26,94–102]. For example, hydrazine hydrate and borohydride are two of the most commonly used compounds to form single graphene sheets [94,95]. Remarkably, the preparation of rGO from GO was performed via a sustainable, more efficient and environmentally benign protocol using various plant extracts as stabilizing/reducing agents (Table 1) [64,103–107]. Although other chemical oxidation approaches to fabricate graphite oxide have generally been discussed so far [83,84], methods developed by Hofmann [108], Brodie [109] and Staudenmaier [110] are considerably less applicable for the preparation of nanomaterials in the catalysis field Furthermore, the GO reduction to reduced GO (rGO) can be performed by [64,107–109] reducing agents such as hydrogen, hydrazine, borohydride and especially plant extracts. However, even heating higher than 100 °C in aqueous media can be used to prepare rGO, as depicted in Fig. 3 [94–117]. The direct growth of graphene on different substrates using CVD process has been reported by different groups [118–120]. In general, the CVD process on the hot metallic surfaces is one of the most favorable procedures for high quality, large scale production of graphene without structural defects and with very low and/or even no O2 content. Various novel advances in CVD preparation by metal precursors such as copper [121], gold [122], iridium [123], platinum [124], etc. have been reported. In CVD preparation, Ni and Cu are among the favored metal precursors [114,125–127]. Various gases such as hydrocarbons (methane, acetylene and ethylene), Ar and H2 can be released into the chamber and decomposed at high temperatures to form a carbon layer on the metal precursor surfaces. Fig. 4 depicts the proposed mechanism for graphene production by CVD process using metal precursors owing to the templating effect of metals [114,128]. Similarly, a single or multi-layer graphene on the polycrystalline Ni precursors (1∼2 cm2) was prepared by Reina and co-workers by the reaction of Ni catalyst and gaseous methane in a CVD chamber at a high temperature (<1000 °C) [129]. Fig. 4b shows graphene preparation through CVD method using Ni substrate [128]. In another work, Chen et al. prepared graphene foam (GF) via an in situ CVD process by Ni foam as the substrate, followed by etching of Ni foam by PMMA [poly(methyl methacrylate)] as a thin layer support to barricade the prevent graphene skeleton from crumbling (Fig. 5 a) [130]. PMMA support layer was removed using acetone and a graphene foam containing an interconnected network (GF-PMMA) was subsequently achieved. The morphology of GF can also be confirmed by SEM and TEM images (Fig. 5b-d). 3 Heterogeneous catalytic mechanism for graphene-mediated reduction of nitroarenes The use of graphene and GO in catalysis started in the recent years after the pioneering research of Bielaswki and co-workers, who used GO-based catalysts for benzyl alcohol oxidation [131]. Although several papers have focused on graphene preparation and its application in catalysis, this field is nascent. Therefore, there are few reports on the GO-based (nano)catalysts compared to other types of carbon family. In addition, recent efforts in this subject have been concentrated on the preparation methods of graphene-based nanocatalysts, preserving the graphene unique properties and its excellent applications as well as precisely tuning their physical and chemical features. Given the added value of graphene and particularly GO-based nanomaterials as alternative nanocatalysts, their ability and sustainability compared to metal/metal oxide nanocatalysts, this emerging area is expected to grow noticeably for many years to come. The basis for a catalytic cycle in which GO can transfer a certain percentage of oxygen from the sheet to an organic substrate or hydrogen to form an oxidized product or water is the capability of GO for reduction of its oxygen content in a certain degree toward rGO and then rGO to become oxidized (Scheme 4 ) [114]. As depicted in Scheme 4, the resulting rGO can be also oxidized using O2 at high temperatures and/or using another oxidizing reagent. The mechanism is based on Mars van Krevelen by cycling between two half reactions, i.e., with higher and lower O2-content. Although several reports have been published on the reduction of nitroarene pollutants using metal/metal oxide NPs via employing various hydrogen sources, only a few efforts have been carried out towards the description of reduction mechanism of nitroarenes in the presence of graphene-based (nano)catalysts and aqueous reductants. In general, the mechanism of nitroarene reduction [132–135] using graphene-based nanocatalysts is presently under investigation. Some common reductants, as more efficient hydrogen sources, such as H2 [136,137], NaBH4 [5,6,138], H3NBH3 (ammonia borane) [139], LiAlH4 (lithium aluminum hydride) [140] and NH2NH2·H2O [141,142] have been recently reported in the literature. Usually, graphene and particularly GO-based nanocatalysts have attracted attention as promising catalytic (nano)systems in the NaBH4-mediated nitroarene reduction in water. In this context, graphene and particularly GO-based materials have been used in the reduction process wherein diverse metal/metal oxide NPs were immobilized on the graphene surface and directly utilized as nanocatalysts in various reductions of toxic nitroarenes by NaBH4. Among diverse reducing agents, NaBH4 has been widely considered a favored water soluble reductant and preferred alternative to hydrogen in the hydrogenation of toxic nitroarenes to significant aminoarenes in aqueous solutions. The activation of NaBH4 is a general process, which requires metal substrates as active sites because metal hydride complexes prepared from the BH4 − ions through a π-π stacking interaction have been considered intermediates in this type of reduction. Thus, one of the aims of catalysis must be to find appropriate graphene-based catalysts, which can also be used in this benchmark transformation. A number of reports have indicated that nanocatalysts can mediate reductive processes of nitroarenes using the above reducing agents via a catalytic mechanism of enhanced electron transfer [6,142–146]. Type of reductants and result on this nitroarene process have been well presented by Kadam and Tilve in 2015 [147]. Thus, we just discuss a few examples of the reduction reaction triggered using borohydride, hydrazine and hydrogen. For a better understanding of this reaction, researchers have studied the hydrogenation route proposed by Haber [148]. Generally, one is the admitted direct path and another is the condensation path. In the direct path, the whole reaction is fairly convenient and very fast. The transformation of nitroaromatics to aminoaromatics can occur in a three step procedure involving nitrosobenzene and the corresponding hydroxylamine (Scheme 5 ). Nitroso compounds were first reduced to nitroso groups. Subsequently, a second equivalent H2 can form hydroxylamine. Consecutively, the equivalent aniline is produced in the rate determining step by adding a third equivalent of H2. Unlike in the condensation path, it can be proposed that azobenzene, hydrazobenzene, and azoxybenzene by-products can be prepared through the formation of two intermediates (Scheme 5). Thereby, the condensation path is extremely tedious. Dhakshinamoorthy et al. elaborated on the reduction of nitro to amino compounds in the presence of nano CeO2 catalyst by hydrazine hydrate as the reductant under mild conditions [149]. The nitroarene hydrogenation to aminoarenes was selectively sensitive (up to 93 %) only for nitro compounds. The plausible mechanism for the reduction of nitroarenes is illustrated in Scheme 6 . Nano CeO2 initially reacts with hydrazine hydrate reductant to produce molecular hydrogen and detaches on nano-CeO2 surface. Nitroarene reduction is then performed via the adsorption of nitroarenes to nano CeO2 surfaces and transfer of the dissociated hydrogens to the nitrosobenzene intermediate. This intermediate forms hydroxyaminobenzenes with the dissociated hydrogens, which then undergo more reduction to achieve aminoarenes as the final product (Scheme 6). In the aforesaid processes, the nitroarene reduction was proposed using NH2NH2·H2O and H2 as the reducing agent. However, reduction by NaBH4 is mostly diverse. Numerous efforts have been performed to expose the exact mechanistic properties of these reactions although the exact mechanism has not yet been determined. In this context, Layek and his research group described a plausible mechanism for surface reduction in the presence of Nano Active™ Magnesium Oxide Plus (NAP-Mg-Au NPs) in nitroarene reduction using NaBH4 reductant (Scheme 7 ) [150]. A B–H bond cleavage can first occur in the rate determining step to form the [NAP-Mg-Au NPs]-H species. Such intermediates are responsible for the reduction of nitroarenes into the corresponding phenylhydroxylamine. Generally, a mechanistic pathway including nitroarene → nitrosoarene → hydroxylamine → aminoarene is the most possible route. Similarly, Gupta et al. reported the six electron transfer reaction between nitroarenes (4-NP and 2-NP) with NaBH4 reductant [151]. However, Lykakis and co-workers reported that nitrosoarene intermediate followed the pathways of nitroarene → hydroxylamine → aminoarene in 2014 [152]. In another work, Nasrollahzadeh⁠ et al. reported graphene catalyzed reduction of toxic 4-NP using NaBH4 through the interaction of π-π stacking (Scheme 8 ) [6]. In the presence of NaBH4 reductant, the Cu/GO/MnO2 nanocatalyst in the 4-NP reduction showed a synergetic effect with GO/MnO2 NPs and Cu NPs by combining the both advantages. They presented a general mechanistic path (Scheme 8). They believed that Cu/GO/MnO2 converts NaBH4 to molecular H2 (and also BO2 −), which is dissociated on the surface nanocatalyst. 4-NP is then adsorbed on the Cu/GO/MnO2 surface such that the interaction with these dissociated H2 species and the 4-NP reduction happen in a step-wise manner to prepare 4-AP. As illustrated in Scheme 8, the resulting 4-AP is finally desorbed from the surface of Cu/GO/MnO2 and another catalytic run starts afresh. Herein, the main role of Cu/GO/MnO2 nanocatalyst is mostly to adsorb the molecular hydrogen and 4-NP in the close proximity to facilitate simple reduction to 4-AP. 4 Graphene-based (nano)catalysts in the reduction of nitro compounds 4.1 GO and rGO Chen et al. investigated the electrocatalytic activity of nitrogen doped graphene (NG) as an effective catalyst for the electrochemical reduction of explosive nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) such as 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT) and 1,3,5-trinitrobenzenein (TNB) in 2012 [153]. For the first time in 2015, Colunga and colleagues discovered GO as an electron shuttle for the reduction of pollutants such as 3-chloronitrobenzene (3CNB) and reactive red 2 (RR2) using biogenic sulfide as the electron donor [154]. Graphene oxide nanocatalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic prowess in the 3CNB reduction to the corresponding amine with high yield. Trandafir and colleagues developed a protocol for the reduction of aromatic and aliphatic nitroarenes to amino groups via hydrogen as a reagent a year later [155]. In this work, graphene obtained by alginate pyrolysis at 900 °C under inert atmosphere and exfoliation was applied as a metal free catalyst. In 2018, Mahata and colleagues reported an efficient, economic and green methodology for the fabrication of GO by cashew leaf extract as a biorenewable reductant [156]. According to the FT-IR analysis of pure cashew leaf extract, electron rich reduction agents such as flavonoids, tannins, alkaloids, and phenolic compounds (quercetin, catechin, tetramer of proanthrocyanidin, gallic acids, anacardiac acids etc.) present in the extract formed the GO. Furthermore, this polyphenol part acts via reactive carbonyl and hydroxyl groups in GO by nucleophilic attack via the release of H2O and generation of rGO. The green synthesized rGO displayed high catalytic prowess in the transformation of nitrobenzene into aniline by hydrazine hydrate in water at 70 °C. 4.2 Au/graphene-based nanocomposites Adhikari and co-workers discovered GO-based supramolecular hydrogels in 2012 by using biologically active polyamines such as tris(aminoethyl)amine, spermine and spermidine [157]. Furthermore, they developed a green process for the production of Ag, Au, and Pt NPs including RGO-based hybrid hydrogels via the reduction of the metal ions and GO gel by vitamin C as a reductant. According to the obtained results, the metal NPs were uniformly supported on the RGO nanosheet surface in the hybrid gel. Catalytic application of the Au NPs/RGO based hybrid hydrogel matrix was investigated in 4-NP and 4-NA reduction to form 4-AP and 4-diphenyleneamine, respectively, at ambient temperature (Scheme 9 ). The synthesized catalyst can be recovered and reused for various cycles without significant loss of catalytic activity. Fakhri and co-workers reported an easy process for the synthesis of GO/Au NPs in 2014 (Fig. 6 ) [158]. The synthesized GO/Au NPs were applied as very active catalysts in the reduction of nitro compounds at ambient temperature using NaBH4 (Scheme 10 ). The catalyst could be recycled and reused for successive various cycles. In 2015, Rajesh and colleagues developed an effective methodology for the production of Ag and Au NPs immobilized on the surface of GO functionalized with chitosan via reduction with NaBH4 (Fig. 7 ) [159]. The GO-Chit-Ag/Au NPs was used as an effective nanocatalyst in the reduction of nitro compounds by NaBH4 (Scheme 11 ). Finally, the nanocatalyst could be easily separated by centrifugation and reused for ten cycles. Pourjavadi and colleagues reported a straightforward approach for the fabrication of magnetic graphene oxide (mGO) improved by polyaniline (PANI) support for Au NPs in 2017 (Fig. 8 ) [160]. The synthesized, recyclable and heterogeneous PANI@mGO-Au catalyst displayed excellent catalytic prowess in the reduction reaction of pollutants such as 4-NP, Rhodamine B (RhB), Methylene Blue (MB) and Congo Red (CR) by NaBH4 at room temperature. Furthermore, the catalyst could be simply separated from the reaction mixtures by applying an external magnet and reused for five successive cycles. In 2018, Vellaichamy and colleagues developed a bio-inspired technique for the ultrasonical fabrication of Au NPs-decorated RGO via reduction of Au ions on the surface of GO by the extract of Simarouba glauca leaves as a reducing and capping agent (Scheme 12 ) [161]. Au NPs are well dispersed on RGO via comparatively identical particle shapes (spherical) and sizes (12 nm). Au NPs@RGO showed remarkable catalytic prowess in the reduction reaction of pollutants such as 2-NP and 4-NP by NaBH4 (Scheme 13 ). In addition, the synthesized catalyst demonstrated great stability even after 10 catalytic cycles. In the same year, Li and colleagues developed a method for the fabrication of the new MXene-gold NPs (MXene@AuNPs) composites with layered MXene (Ti3C2-(OH x F1- x )2) as a model for the direct reduction of Au NPs in HAuCl4 solution at room temperature (Fig. 9 ) [162]. The synthesized special structural composites with optimized reduction time displayed high catalytic performance for some nitroarenes, such as 2-NA and 4-NP. Finally, the MXene@AuNPs composite indicated great stability even after 8 successive catalytic cycles. Nabid and colleagues developed an efficient and single step process for the fabrication of MoS2 nanosheets on nitrogen doped graphene (MoS2/NG) as an active support to decorate Au NPs in 2018 [163]. They studied the catalytic activity of AuNPs@MoS2/NG in the reduction of 4-NP by NaBH4 as a reductant. They showed that the catalyst could be effectively employed to reduce nitroarenes. The catalyst can be reused for four successive times. In the same year, Naeem and colleagues reported a facile protocol for the production of GO-Au nanocomposite by reducing Au(III) ions using Na3C6H5O7 as a reducing agent [164]. The GO-Au nanocomposite displayed high removal activities for industrial dyes such as ethyl violet (EV), methyl orange (MO) and malachite green (MG) in H2O. The mentioned nanocomposite exhibited high catalytic prowess in the 2-NA reduction by NaBH4 in aqueous medium (Fig. 10 ). 4.3 Ag/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2013, Jeon and colleagues developed a straightforward and facile methodology for the fabrication of Ag NPs on GO nanosheet surface functionalized with the mussel inspired dopamine (GO-Dopa) (Fig. 11 ) [165]. The TEM images (Fig. 12 ) confirmed the formation of Ag NPs with average sizes of 7.71 ± 1.34 nm and good dispersion on the GO-Dopa sheets as supports to overcome the agglomeration problem. The dopamine functionalized GO sheets operated as reducing and stabilizing agents in Ag+ ions reduction at room temperature in water. The green synthesized Ag/GO-Dopa hybrid displayed high catalytic prowess as a heterogeneous catalyst in the reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP using NaBH4. Paul and co-workers proposed a straightforward and novel strategy for hydrothermal fabrication of Ag/Fe2O3 decorated rGO nanocomposite by urea and polyethylene glycol (PEG 4000) as the hydroxylating agent and surfactant in 2016 (Fig. 13 ) [166]. According to the obtained results, the synthesized Ag/Fe2O3-rGO nanocomposite was applied as an effective catalyst in the reduction of nitro compounds to the corresponding amines (Scheme 14 ). The heterogeneous catalyst could be simply recovered using an external magnet and reused five times. A year later, an ecofriendly, short time and sonochemical approach was developed by Ganguly and colleagues for the production of spherical Ag NPs decorated graphene sheets by applying carbon dots as green reducing and stabilizing agent (Fig. 14 ) [167]. The carboxylic, hydroxyl and amine moieties at the surface of the C-dots act as nucleation centers for the growth of Ag NPs. They employed RGO-Ag nanocomposite as an efficient catalyst in the reduction of nitroarene pollutant (Fig. 15 ). The RGO-Ag nanocomposite could be reused for five successive times. 4.4 Pd/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2014, Li and colleagues reported a successful methodology for the preparation of ultrafine Pd nanocrystals (PdNCs) immobilized on the SnO2-decorated graphene nanosheets via immobilization of Pd NPs with 3.4 nm average size on the PDDA functionalized SnO2-GNS (SnO2-GNS) (Fig. 16 ) [168]. The synthesized PdNCs/SnO2-GNS was applied in 4-NP reduction using NaBH4. Nasrollahzadeh and colleagues developed an efficient, green and mild technique for the fabrication of Pd NPs by barberry fruit extract in 2016 (Scheme 15 ) [169]. In this work, Pd NPs were decorated on RGO for preventing agglomeration and simplification of their separation. According to the FE-SEM analysis of the Pd NPs/RGO (Fig. 17 ), large amounts of the Pd NPs were distributed on the RGO surfaces. Pd NPs/RGO show remarkable catalytic performance in nitroarene reduction by NaBH4 in an EtOH and H2O (1:2) mixture (Scheme 16 ). The catalyst could be easily reused for 5 successive cycles. In the same year, Liu and co-workers reported a straightforward process for the fabrication of UiO66@RGO-Pd nanocomposites via encapsulating Pd NPs onto Zr-MOFs@RGO (UiO66@RGO) support (Fig. 18 ) [170]. The crystalline UiO66@RGO-Pd showed microporous and mesoporous structures with high porosity. According to the obtained results, UiO66@RGO-Pd nanocomposites presented remarkable catalytic prowess in the reduction of nitro compounds due to their well-defined pore structure and large surface area. The synthesized catalyst could be recycled and reused for six times without significant loss of catalytic activity. In 2018, Yazdankhah and colleagues used a new technique for the fabrication of rGO-Pd NPs hybrid (Pd NPs/FGO) using Fritillaria imperialis flower extract [171]. Based on their findings in this study, the extract could successfully reduce Pd(II) ions and GO and adsorb Pd NPs on the rGO surface. The Pd NPs/FGO nanohybrid shows significant catalytic prowess in 4-NP reduction (Scheme 17 ). The nanocatalyst could be reused for eight successive cycles. Zhang et al. developed a straightforward technique for the synthesis of Pd NPs immobilized on GO surface in the same year [172]. Pd/GO nanocatalyst demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity in nitroaromatic reduction by NaBH4 (Scheme 18 ). The high catalytic performance of Pd/GO is due to the equal dispersion and huge surface area relation of Pd NPs on GO. The heterogeneous nanocatalyst could be reused for six cycles. 4.5 Ni/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2017, Kubendhiran et al. successfully developed an efficient and simple approach for the production of green RGO/nickel tetraphenyl porphyrin (GRGO/Ni-TPP) nanocomposite modified electrode via reduction of GO with caffeic acid (CA) and the non-covalent π-π stacking interaction between Ni-TPP and RGO (Fig. 19 ) [173]. In this study, GRGO/Ni-TPP was used for nitrobenzene (NB) electrochemical detection in different water samples. According to the obtained results, the GRGO/Ni-TPP modified electrode displayed high selectivity and significant recovery in the determination of NB. In the same year, Karthik and colleagues employed a green strategy for the fabrication of RGO-Ni nanocomposite using l-ascorbic acid as a capping and reducing agent in the reduction of GO and NiCl2.6H2O under hydrothermal conditions [174]. The synthesized RGO-Ni heterogeneous catalyst displayed high catalytic performance in the nitroaromatic reduction by NaBH4 in water under mild conditions (Scheme 19 ). The synthesized catalyst could be recovered by magnetic separation and reused for 5 successive cycles. 4.6 Pt/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2015, Li and co-workers successfully used an efficient and simple approach for the fabrication of rGO decorated platinum nanocubes (Pt-NCs/rGO) via water based, co-chemical reduction process using polyallylamine hydrochloride as a multi-functional agent in the functionalization of GO [175]. Pt-NCs/rGO composite displayed high catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of 4-NP by NaBH4. Finally, the catalyst could be recycled and reused for 5 successive cycles. Sahoo and colleagues reported a green and economic technique for the fabrication of metals (Au, Pd and Pt)/3D-graphene nanocomposites using GO and metal precursors in 2017 [176]. The metals/3D-graphene nanocomposites are very active in 4-NP and MB reduction using NaBH4 at ambient temperature. The reaction rates are in the order, Pt/ > Pd/ >Au/3D-graphene for both the pollutants, indicating that the minimum metal NPs have the excellent catalytic action. The synthesized nanocomposites could be simply reused for five successive cycles. 4.7 Cu/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2018, a simple approach was developed by Liu and Guo for the fabrication of SH-β-CD-RGO/CuNSs nanocomposite by facile chemical deposition of Cu nanospheres (CuNSs) on thio-β-cyclodextrin (SH-β-CD) functionalized RGO (SH-β-CD-RGO) [177]. The nanocomposite functioned as an improved material in the quantitative analysis of 4-NP in H2O. The RGO-MNPs hybrid system showed excellent catalytic prowess in the aromatic nitro reduction. In 2014, Feng and colleagues reported a straightforward procedure for the fabrication of graphene decorated Pd-Cu NPs via co-reduction of CuCl2.H2O and PdCl2 [180]. According to the obtained results in this study, the Pd Cu-graphene could be reused for six successive times. Göksu and colleagues developed a straightforward methodology for the synthesis of rGO supported Co30Pd70 alloy (rGO-Co30Pd70) NPs by co-reduction of cobalt(II) and Pd(II) acetylacetonates in borane-tert-butylamine (BTB) and oleylamine (OAm) mixture in 2013 [181]. The rGO-Co30Pd70 catalyst displayed high catalytic prowess in the reduction of aromatic nitro compounds to the corresponding amines using ammonia borane in H2O/methanol mixture (Scheme 23 ). In 2015, Fang and colleagues developed a simple and green approach for production of graphene/CuNi nanocomposite [182]. In this work, graphene supported CuNi NPs with 2D structure particles size of ∼2 nm were immobilized on the graphene sheets. The graphene/CuNi nanocomposite was active in the selective reduction of nitro aromatic by NaBH4 (Scheme 24 ). Furthermore, the catalyst could be recycled and reused for 25 times. Metin and colleagues have reported a facile methodology for the preparation of monodisperse Ag/Pd core/shell NPs assembled on RGO in 2017 [183]. RGO@Ag/Pd was used in nitroarene hydrogenation in the presence of ammonia borane (AB) in aqueous methanol solution (Fig. 22 ). RGO@Ag/Pd was fabricated via thermal decomposition of palladium(II) bromide over the as-prepared Ag NPs in a mixture of oleic acid and oleylamine at 220 °C. Affording to the obtained results in this study, the catalyst was highly efficient (>99 % yield in 5−15 min) in nitroarene reduction to the corresponding amines. In the same year, Dhanda and Kidwai employed a new technique for the preparation of the graphene decorated Rux Ni100-x alloy NPs (x = 25, 50, 75 and 100) with a particle size of <5 nm [184]. Nanocomposites show extraordinary activity in AB hydrolytic dehydrogenation. The alloy nanocomposite is very active in the reduction of nitro and nitrile compounds by AB as the H2 source and the results displayed high performance with high yield (> 99 %) of the amine product in 4.5−10 min (Scheme 25 ). Based on the experimental results, among various RuNi alloy compositions, Ru50Ni50 catalyst displayed the best performance in terms of catalytic stability and activity. 4.9 CdS/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2013, Chen et al. reported a two-step protocol for the production of the uniform CdS nanospheres/graphene hybrid nanocomposite through an electrostatic self-assembly process combined with a facile hydrothermal treatment [185]. The CdS NSPs/GR hybrid nanocomposite exhibited excellent photocatalytic performance in the selective reduction of aromatic nitro compounds (Fig. 23 ). The excellent photocatalytic activity of CdS NSPs/GR hybrid nanocomposite can be attributed to the improved lifetime, high absorptivity, transfer of charge carriers and addition of NH4HCO2 as a quencher for photogenerated holes. Liu and colleagues employed an electrostatic self-assembly technique for the preparation of CdS nanowires-rGO (CdS NWs-RGO NCs) in the same year. In this method, the conversion of GO to RGO was carried out via hydrothermal reduction [186]. The synthesized CdS NWs-RGO NCs were applied as active photocatalysts in the selective reduction of nitro compounds in the aqueous medium under visible light irradiation and in the presence of NH4HCO2 at room temperature (Fig. 24 ). More adsorption capacity, better lifetime and enhanced transfer of photogenerated charge cause the improvement of the photocatalytic prowess of the catalyst compared to the original CdS NWs. In 2014, Weng and co-workers successfully developed an effective and simple technique for the fabrication of CdS NWs-CNT nanocomposites (NCs) by room temperature self-assembly approach via electrostatic significant interaction between the negatively charged CNT and positively charged CdS NWs in aqueous medium in the absence of any polyelectrolytes (Fig. 25 ) [187]. The synthesized CdS NWs-CNT NCs demonstrated high catalytic performance in the reduction of nitro organic compounds by ammonium formate in H2O under visible light irradiation (Fig. 26 ). A year later, Han and colleagues developed a modest and efficient method for the fabrication of CdS nanowire nitrogen doped graphene (CdS NWs-NGR) nanocomposite via hydrothermal method by electrostatic interaction between the positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged reduced NGR (Fig. 27 ) [188]. The nanocomposite showed high photoactivity prowess in the selective reduction of nitroarenes containing −OH, -NH2, -OMe, and -Me groups under visible light irradiation in water. In 2016, Peng et al. proposed a straightforward technique for the synthesis of the composite consisting of CdS NPs grown on the MoS2/rGO hybrid surface (Fig. 28 ) [189]. According to the obtained results in this study, the CdS-MoS2/rGO composite displayed high photocatalytic performance compared with the pure CdS in the 4-NP reduction to 4-AP using NH4HCO2 as the sacrificial agent under visible light (Scheme 26 ). 4.10 TiO2/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2013, Xu et al. reported a method for the fabrication of TiO2-graphene (TiO2-G) hybrids using an electrostatic assembly and in situ photocatalytic reduction [190]. They investigated the performance of the TiO2-G hybrids in the photocatalytic reduction of nitro to amino compounds using hole scavengers. According to the obtained results in this study, the addition of graphene sheets to TiO2 remarkably improved the reduction of nitro organic compounds (Fig. 29 ). A mild method was developed by Pan and colleagues for the fabrication of ultra large graphene-based TiO2 (GR@TiO2) nanocomposite via non-covalent functionalization in the presence of benzyl alcohol as a linking agent (Fig. 30 ) one year later [191]. The GR@TiO2 nanocomposite was synthesized via π-π interaction of the benzene ring of benzyl alcohol with the aromatic network of GR. The synthesized nanocomposite showed high photocatalytic performance in the reduction of the nitroarenes in H2O at ambient temperature (Scheme 27 ). In 2016, Xu and colleagues developed the hydrothermal fabrication of the holey graphene sheets involving TiO2 using H2O2 to etch the carbon sheets [192]. They also reported the photocatalytic performance of graphene involved TiO2 hybrids and traditional graphene sheets in the reduction of 4-NP (Fig. 31 ). According to the obtained results in this study, the photocatalysis activity of graphene involved TiO2 hybrids could be enhanced by the introduction of holey structure in these carbon sheets. A year later, Yadav and colleagues reported a novel and combined method for the production of RGO/W-doped TiO2 nanocomposite [193]. The prepared composite was used as a photocatalyst in the degradation of 4-NP (87 %) in 180 min. 4.11 Co3O4/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2015, Jagadeesh and colleagues developed an effective and simple technique for the creation of cobalt-based nanoparticles surrounded by nitrogen-doped graphene layers (NGrs) via pyrolysis of phenanthroline-ligated Co(OAc)2 on carbon [194]. The Co3O4/NGr@C nanocatalyst displayed high catalytic performance in nitrobenzene hydrogenation using 50 bar H2 in THF and water at 110 °C with conversion of >99 % and 95 yield. Finally, the synthesized catalyst could be recycled and reused for various times. Pervaiz et al. developed a simple technique for the fabrication of nitrogen doped RGO-Co3O4 nanograin cookies in 2017 [195]. The synthesized N-RGO-Co3O4 catalyst with huge surface area (1085.6 m2/g) and pore density (0.47 m3/g) microcages displayed high catalytic prowess in the reduction of aromatic nitro compounds. N-RGO-Co3O4 showed the highest yield in the 4-NP reduction (96 %) at ambient temperature in comparison with pure Co3O4 and RGO-Co3O4 nanograin. 4.12 CuCo2O4/graphene-based nanocomposites In 2016, Zhang and colleagues reported a low cost procedure for the production of CuCo2O4/RGO heterocomposite [196]. The TEM image displayed that the RGO sheets were supported with a large quantity of CuCo2O4 NPs with 18−22 nm size range (Fig. 32 ). According to the obtained results in this study, the CuCo2O4/RGO composite showed excellent catalytic activity in 4-NP reduction using NaBH4 in 6 min. Furthermore, the CuCo2O4/RGO composite showed excellent stability and reusability. 4.13 NiWO4-ZnO/graphene-based nanocomposite In 2017, Sadiq and colleagues effectively developed the synthesis of NiWO4-ZnO-NRGO ternary nanocomposite by decorating nitrogen doped rGO (NRGO) with ZnO and NiWO4 NPs by a facile microwave irradiation method [197]. The nanocomposite can be used for the photodegradation of MB dye in water medium. According to the experimental results, the catalytic performance of the synthesized catalyst was almost nine times higher than that of NiWO4 and it exhibited high stability even after five cycles. Moreover, the nanocomposite exhibited high catalytic activity in the reduction of 4-NP using NaBH4 as the reducing agent (Fig. 33 ). 4.14 BaWO4/graphene-based nanocomposites Sadiq and colleagues reported a new and one-pot microwave technique for the synthesis of the BaWO4/NRGO-g-C3N4 nanocomposite a year later [198]. They employed BaWO4/NRGO-g-C3N4 as an efficient catalyst in the photodegradation of MB in H2O in 120 min. and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Furthermore, the catalyst displayed high catalytic prowess in the reduction of 4-NP using NaBH4 as a reductant at ambient temperature in 60 s (Fig. 34 ). BaWO4/NRGO-g-C3N4 exhibited remarkable catalytic prowess even after 10 cycles, in 92 s and nearly 100 % conversion. 5 Summary and discussion The graphene-based (nano)catalysts utilized in the reduction of nitro compounds are summarized in Table 2 [199–245]. Having reviewed the corresponding reports, it became apparent that there are no particular rules to predict the results of catalytic reduction. Generally, the catalytic prowess of catalysts depends on their size, surface area, composition, fabrication method, morphology and reaction conditions [246–252]. 6 Conclusion and future prospects Nitroarenes are harmful compounds, which commonly exist in water. The essential goal of this review has preferably been to make a comprehensive reliable reference for scientists worldwide in the field of development of graphene-based (nano)catalysts for important reduction reactions. This review has described recent developments on the use of different catalytic systems to transform nitro compound into beneficial products, which are less harmful for the environment and humans. This was done via GO-support NPs because of their inherent applications in energy storage, electronic devices, sensors and recently catalysis in catalytic reaction of nitroarenes reduction due to their vast surface and extraordinary physicochemical properties. In view of growing applications of graphene-based (nano)catalysts in chemical reduction processes, this review article illustrates different catalytic systems employing transition metals and metal oxides; namely, Pd, Cu, Ni, Au, Pt, Ag, CdS, TiO2, bimetallic NPs, etc. as a nanocatalysts decorated on graphene and their derivatives. This study has shown that the reduction of nitroarenes has been performed using reducing agents and various catalytic systems. Representative procedures for the fabrication of such (nano)catalysts by GO and metal/metal oxide NPs have also been featured. Based on the obtained results from the aforesaid papers in this review, reduction reactions using graphene-based (nano)catalysts have been evaluated multiple times to assure the reproducibility. Generally, these catalytic systems have several advantages such as simplicity of separation, excellent catalytic activity under operationally mild and/or greener reaction conditions and ease of reusability in several successive cycles. Mainly, scalable production of sustainable, cheap and effective nanocatalysts needs the removal of many barriers in the preparation of GO-based (nano)catalysts on an experimental scale. The future challenges and outlooks are as follows: • Magnetic materials are generally used to separate metal nanocatalysts, but they only function as supports. Some magnetic metal NPs with the capability to reduce nitroarenes such as Ni NPs, can be combined with some metal NPs such as Au NPs to improve the catalytic performance. • Synthesis of irregular metal NPs or bi/multi-metallic NPs is one of the effective alternative methods to improve the catalytic performance due to the synergistic effect or corner and edge effects. • Few of the catalysts are suitable for industrial scale applications. Therefore, the development of catalysts used on an industrial scale is one of the future plans. • Most research has been focused on the reduction of nitro compounds in aqueous solution by NaBH4. However, it is necessary to carry out research in other media such as organic solutions and sediment and soil in the future. • Few papers have focused on the reduction of aliphatic nitro compounds. Therefore, further research should be performed on the mechanism of reduction of nitro aliphatic compounds via appropriate metal based nanocatalysts. • Improvement and efficient utilization of cheap, mild and water soluble reductants in reduction reactions of nitroarenes. • Prevention and limitation of formation of unfavorable and harmful intermediate products during these catalytic conversions. • Development of biological methods using aqueous or alcoholic plant extracts and other biogenic resources for the fabrication of metal NPs along with their stabilization/immobilization on graphene surface under mild/greener conditions, which are safer and more economically beneficial for human and environment. Consequently, simple and new green pathways for the preparation of graphene nanocatalyst with high catalytic efficiency in the reduction of nitroarenes is still a fundamental need to improve the reduction processes in the future. coredata.dc:description: The rapid progresses in the reduction of nitro compounds represent a potent and extensively utilized transformation, which allows the introduction of amino compounds. From the standpoint of organic chemistry, amines have many applications in the synthesis of drugs, biologically active molecules, pharmaceutical products, dyes, polymers, etc. For this aim and owing to the environmental concerns about toxic nitro contaminants such as 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), up to know, much research has been carried out on the reduction/degradation of nitroarenes for the fabrication of amines using different heterogeneous (nano)catalysts. This review provides the current developments in the area of production, classification and applications of graphene-based catalysts in the reduction of nitro compounds to amines. The application of graphene derivatives in the synthesis of various catalysts is advantageous compared to other catalysts and thus increases the rate of reduction of nitro compounds. The use of these catalysts offers several benefits such as straightforward work-up, high catalytic prowess and recovery.
coredata.dc:title: Recent progresses in graphene-based (photo)catalysts for reduction of nitro compounds
